[[Chris Drury]] |AltCaptain=[[Teppo Numminen]] |Arena=[[HSBC Arena (Buffalo)|HSBC Arena]] |Attendance=18,690 |GoalsLeader=[[Thomas Vanek]] (43) |AssistsLeader=Daniel Briere (63) |PointsLeader=Daniel Briere (95) |PIMLeader=[[Adam Mair]] (128) |PlusMinusLeader=Thomas Vanek (+47) |WinsLeader=[[Ryan Miller]] (40) |GAALeader=Ryan Miller (2.73) |PresidentsTrophy=Yes |DivisionWin=Yes }} The '''[[2006â07 NHL season|2006â07]] [[Buffalo Sabres]] [[Season (sports)|season]]''' began with the team attempting to rebound from a disappointing end to the [[2005â06 NHL season|2005â06 season]], in which the Sabres advanced to the [[Eastern Conference (NHL)|Eastern Conference]] Finals before losing in seven games to the eventual [[Stanley Cup]] champion [[Carolina Hurricanes]]. With the best regular-season record in the NHL, the Sabres were awarded the [[Presidents' Trophy]] for the first time in their history, and they also earned the top seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs. They defeated the [[New York Islanders]] and [[New York Rangers]] in the first two rounds of the playoffs. In the Eastern Conference Finals, however, the Sabres' season came to an end when they were defeated in five games by the [[Ottawa Senators]]. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Offseason== The team lost several veterans to free agency, including [[Jean-Pierre Dumont|J. P. Dumont]], [[Jay McKee]] and [[Mike Grier]]. Conversely, the team signed only one new player to the roster: [[Defenceman (ice hockey)|defenseman]] [[Jaroslav Å paÄek|Jaroslav Spacek]]. The team planned to rely on young players from their own organization â [[JiÅÃ­ NovotnÃ½ (ice hockey)|Jiri Novotny]], [[Paul Gaustad]] and [[Nathan Paetsch]], to name a fewâto fill the holes left by the departing players. Controversy swirled around the team's logo and jersey, meanwhile, as the look was changed. The team's colors were reverted back to blue and gold, which they had worn from their addition to the league as an expansion team until [[1996â97 NHL season|1996â97]], when the colors were changed to black and red. The new logo, though, was said to resemble to many a slug or a wig. There were strong efforts to prevent the team from wearing this new jersey, although none were successful. The team's new third jersey, meanwhile, featured the team's original logo. Despite the controversy, however, the NHL reported that sales of Sabres merchandise were up approximately 1170% from the 2005â2006 season.{{cite news | first = Garth | last = | title = SABRES TOP NHL.COM MERCHANDISE SALES | url = http://www.hockeybuzz.com/blog.php?post_id=3561 | publisher = Hockeybuzz.com | date =2006-11-07 | accessdate =2007-01-02 }} ==Regular season== The Sabres were very successful early in the season, tying an NHL record by winning their first ten games, before finally suffering a shootout loss to the [[Atlanta Thrashers]].{{cite news |title= Thrashers put an end to Sabres' bid for NHL record start |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/recap?gameId=261028002 |publisher= espn.com |date= 2006-10-28 |accessdate= 2007-03-04 }} They did not lose a game in regulation until exactly one month into the season, in their thirteenth game, when they lost to [[Toronto Maple Leafs|Toronto]].{{cite news |title= Sundin, Maple Leafs hand Sabres first loss in regulation |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/recap?gameId=261104002 |publisher= espn.com |date= 2006-11-04 |accessdate= 2007-03-04 }} The Sabres also set an NHL record by winning their first ten road games of the season,{{cite news |title= Sabres defeat Canes, bump road record to 10â0 |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/recap?gameId=261113007 |publisher= espn.com |date= 2006-11-13 |accessdate= 2007-03-04 }} not losing outside of [[HSBC Arena (Buffalo)|HSBC Arena]] until November 18 in [[Ottawa Senators|Ottawa]]. On January 9, it was announced that three members of the Sabres had been voted to start the [[55th National Hockey League All-Star Game|All-Star Game]] for the Eastern Conference: forward [[Daniel BriÃ¨re|Daniel Briere]], defenseman [[Brian Campbell]], and goaltender [[Ryan Miller]]. It was the first All-Star appearance for each.{{cite news |title= 2006â07 NHL All-Star Rosters |url= http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/feature/?fid=9182 |publisher= tsn.ca |date= 2007-01-09 |accessdate= 2007-01-15 }} In addition, as the Sabres had the best record in the Eastern Conference as of the end of All-Star voting, head coach [[Lindy Ruff]] was assigned to coach the Eastern Conference team.{{cite news |title= Ruff, Carlyle to coach All-Star teams |url=http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=190825&hubname= |publisher= tsn.ca |date= 2007-01-04 |accessdate= 2007-01-15 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070107090003/http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=190825&hubname= |archivedate = 2007-01-07}} Briere recorded a goal and four assists in the game, and was named Most Valuable Player of the game.{{cite news |title=Briere shines, but West wins All-Star Game |url=http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=193486&hubname= |publisher= tsn.ca |date= 2007-01-25 |accessdate= 2007-01-25 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[Thomas Vanek]] was also invited to All-Star Weekend to play in the YoungStars game.{{cite news |title= NHL's bright future is on display |url= http://www.nhl.com/nhl/app/?service=page&page=NewsPage&articleid=287353 |publisher= nhl.com |date= 2007-01-13 |accessdate= 2007-01-15 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On January 13, [[Jason Pominville]] recorded his 20th goal of the season, becoming the fourth Sabre (after [[Chris Drury]], [[Thomas Vanek]] and [[Maxim Afinogenov]]) to record 20 goals before the All-Star break. At the time of Pominville's 20th goal, no other team in the NHL had more than two players with 20 goals.{{cite news |title= Richards nets tiebreaker in Lightning win over Sabres |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/recap?gameId=270113002 |publisher= espn.com |date= 2007-01-13 |accessdate= 2007-01-15 }} [[Daniel BriÃ¨re|Daniel Briere]] became the fifth Sabre to record 20 goals as he scored a [[hat trick]] on January 30 against the [[Boston Bruins]]. With the feat, the Sabres became the first team since the [[1995â96 NHL season|1995â96 Pittsburgh Penguins]] to have five 20âgoal scorers before February.{{cite news |title= Drury leads the Sabres over Bruins |url= http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=194540&hubname=nhl |publisher= tsn.ca |date= 2007-02-01 |accessdate= 2007-02-02 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Four Sabres would go on to reach the 30-goal plateau. For the first time in 12 years, Buffalo was not shut out in any of their 82 regular-season games. Moreover, the Sabres led the NHL in goals scored and became the first team to score at least 200 even-strength goals during the regular season since the 2000-01 New Jersey Devils. In February, the Sabres found themselves battling injury problems. Forward [[Tim Connolly]] had been on the long-term injury list all season, and he was joined by [[Paul Gaustad]] when a tendon in his leg was sliced on February 7 against the [[Ottawa Senators]]. [[Jaroslav Å paÄek|Jaroslav Spacek]] broke his left hand soon thereafter, and the Sabres lost [[Maxim Afinogenov]], who broke his left wrist, and [[JiÅÃ­ NovotnÃ½ (ice hockey)|Jiri Novotny]] with a high ankle sprain. [[AleÅ¡ KotalÃ­k|Ales Kotalik]] was next to go down, with a knee sprain, and forward [[Daniel Paille]] broke his finger. Against the [[Ottawa Senators]] on February 22, captain [[Chris Drury]] was injured by a blow to the head by [[Chris Neil]], sparking a wild brawl which saw a fight between [[Martin Biron]] and Senators goaltender [[Ray Emery]], and later between Emery and Sabres enforcer [[Andrew Peters]].{{cite news |title=Sabres outlast Sens in hard-fought battle |url=http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=197259&hubname= |publisher= tsn.ca |date= 2007-02-23 |accessdate= 2007-02-28 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The Sabres were the last team to be involved in a trade in the 2006â07 season. On the day of the [[National Hockey League Trade Deadline|NHL trade deadline]], though, they made four trades. Goaltender [[Martin Biron]], who had been the longest-tenured Sabre, was sent to [[Philadelphia Flyers|Philadelphia]] for Philadelphia's second-round pick in the [[2007 NHL Entry Draft]]. Buffalo's fifth-round pick in that draft was sent to [[Columbus Blue Jackets|Columbus]] in exchange for another backup goalie, [[Ty Conklin]]. Jiri Novotny was sent along with Buffalo's 2007 first-round pick to [[Washington Capitals|Washington]] in exchange for [[Dainius Zubrus]] and [[Timo Helbling]]. Finally, the Sabres sent their fourth-round pick in 2007 to [[Nashville Predators|Nashville]] for [[Mikko Lehtonen (ice hockey b. 1978)|Mikko Lehtonen]], a minor league defenseman.{{cite news |title=Sabres beef up with Zubrus |url=http://www.nhl.com/nhl/app?articleid=289720&page=NewsPage&service=page |publisher= nhl.com |date= 2007-02-27 |accessdate= 2007-02-27 }} {{Dead link|date=October
